name: Embracing Failure and Innovation: Lessons from Punk Rock with Kevin Goldsmith
author: Scott Porad & Brad Hefta-Gaub
summary: In this episode of "How Many CTOs Does It Take?" podcast, hosts Scott Porad and Brad Hefta-Gaub are joined by Kevin Goldsmith, a seasoned tech leader with a background in both music and technology. Kevin shares insights from his early career in the music industry, his journey through various tech roles, and his book 'It Depends'. The discussion covers important topics like learning from failure, managing tech debt, and the impact of AI-assisted coding. Kevin also talks about the value of retrospectives, even after successful projects, and shares experiences from his tenure at Spotify. As a fun bonus Brad and Kevin both discuss their histories as record label owners and conclude by recommending some of their new favorite music.

name: Creative Leadership, Context Over Process, Remote Scaling, AI as Amplifier | Kevin Goldsmith, CTO at DistroKid
author: Yassine Kachchani
summary: In this interview, Kevin Goldsmith, CTO of DistroKid and veteran of companies like Spotify, Adobe, and Microsoft, shares how his artistic background as a musician and photographer deeply informs his creative, empathetic approach to technology leadership. He emphasizes the importance of contextual thinking over rigid adherence to best practices, advocating for leadership strategies tailored to the unique dynamics of each team and situation. Goldsmith highlights the power of diversity, curiosity, and systems thinking in building effective engineering organizations, and explores how AI, rather than replacing engineers, will empower those who ask better questions and focus on higher-order innovation. He also discusses the unique advantages smaller companies have in building global remote teams, including agility, cohesion, and cultural integration.

name: Leadership, Technology, and the “It Depends” Philosophy: Insights from Kevin Goldsmith
author: Etienne de Bruin
summary:
Kevin Goldsmith, a seasoned CTO, mentor, and principal at Nimble Autonomy, joins the conversation today as we discuss Kevin's journey in technology leadership across the US, Sweden, and the UK, touching on his experiences and the release of his new book, It Depends: Writing on Technology Leadership 2012 to 2022.

The discussion covers technology adoption, with a focus on ChatGPT and its recent Teams product. Kevin reveals how his team embraced ChatGPT, its role in policy creation, and the advantages of the Teams program for collaborative work. The conversation unfolds into a deeper exploration of the evolving role of CTOs, the future landscape for aspiring leaders, and the potential impact of advanced tools on development processes.

Kevin, in addition, sheds light on the creation of his book, sharing insights into the inspiration behind the title It Depends and the unique approach that he took in preserving the original context of his blog posts. He touches on the audiobook creation process and the decision to self-release, emphasizing accessibility and convenience for readers.

Kevin also offers us a glimpse into his vision for the future, both in terms of technology leadership and the evolving capabilities of generative text generators like ChatGPT. The candid and insightful conversation provides listeners with a multifaceted view of technology, leadership, and the intricate balance between innovation and the human touch, and you won't want to miss this conversation.

name: Kevin Goldsmith - Chief Technology Officer (CTO) at DistroKid, Board Member, Advisor, and International Speaker
author: Jason Cavness
summary:
Kevin Goldsmith serves as the Chief Technology Officer for DistroKid, the world's largest digital music distributor. Previously, he was the CTO of Anaconda, Inc., the world's most popular data science platform with over 25 million users.

Before joining Anaconda, he served as CTO of AI-powered identity management company Onfido. Other roles have included CTO at Avvo, vice president of engineering, consumer at Spotify, and nine years at Adobe Systems as a director of engineering. He has also held software engineering roles at Microsoft and IBM.

Goldsmith is also the founder and principal at Nimble Autonomy, LLC., where he consults with growing startups working to scale their technology and teams deliberately and thoughtfully and with established companies working to be more innovative and agile in their product development practices.

Kevin is the author of “It Depends: Writing on Technology Leadership 2012-2022” which will be released in March 2024 by Unit Circle Press.

name: Finding the Stream with Kevin Goldsmith
author: Joshua Morgam
summary: In this episode our host Joshua Morgan, Client Director at Godel is joined by Kevin Goldsmith, CTO at DistroKid to talk about Kevin’s career so far and how the ever-changing tech climate has shaped a culture of agile working and distributed teams.

name: Discovering How Over 30-40% of ALL NEW MUSIC is Distributed w/ Distrokid!
author: Elliot Kipling
summary:
Why is DistroKid so popular within the music industry?

Elliot Kipling was lucky enough to be joined by Kevin Goldsmith from DistroKid on Enginears!

name: Scaling Products for a Global Market: Considerations and Challenges
author: Mark Garcia
summary:
On this episode, we're joined by Kevin Goldsmith, Chief Technology Officer at DistroKid. With many years of experience in the tech and digital media industries, Kevin shares his insights on the key considerations and challenges businesses face when scaling a product for a global market.

We discuss:

  • The importance of having a global mindset from the inception of a product.
  • Localization considerations, such as language, marketing, pricing and understanding the differences in connectivity across different regions.
  • Best practices for scaling your technology infrastructure to serve a global market.
  • Why businesses need to prioritize understanding the different privacy laws and other region-specific regulations.
  • Tactics for market research when scaling globally.
  • Why data plays a key role in understanding the effectiveness of your product across different regions.
  • The importance of building a culture of innovation.

      • Kevin says,"I think the one thing I've learned over my 30 years of working in technology has been that I always have to be curious. I always have to be learning. I can never assume that what I know is sufficient for everything else."

name: Kevin Goldsmith: Architecture and Organization
author: Eberhard Wolff
summary: A vital aspect of modern software engineering is to align organizational structures with software architectures to enhance performance. With his extensive experience from Avvo, Spotify, Adobe, and Microsoft, Kevin will discuss the relation between organization and architecture with us. We will not just talk about Conway’s Law but also other aspects like the Homomorphic Force or the Mirroring Hypothesis.

name: What got you there is not gonna keep you there - Kevin Goldsmith, CTO at DistroKid
author: Rob D. Willis
summary:
Ever wondered why some leaders effortlessly climb the corporate ladder while others get stuck? It's not always about skill; it's about evolving with your role.

Tune in to Episode 14 as we chat with Kevin Goldsmith, the CTO at Distrokid. Kevin opens up about his challenging transition from being a developer to managing a rapidly scaling team at renowned companies like Adobe, Spotify, and Microsoft.

We dissect the dangers of being a bottleneck, the importance of self-awareness, and how you can escape the trap of your own making. This episode is your guide to navigating the often-unspoken challenges that come with the responsibilities of scaling teams and companies. Whether you're a seasoned executive or an aspiring leader, we've got insights that can help you level up.

name: CTO Kevin Goldsmith on Leveraging Failure to Drive Success at Spotify and DistroKid
author: Mark Graban
summary:
My guest for Episode #198 of the My Favorite Mistake podcast is Kevin Goldsmith, the chief technology officer at DistroKid, the world’s largest distributor of digital music.

Kevin is an experienced leader of high-profile, high-performing product, research, and shared technology engineering organizations. An often-invited speaker on building strong engineering teams at conferences internationally – often talking about learning from failure. Has extensive experience building products using Lean, Kanban, Scrum, and Extreme Programming methodologies.

In this episode, Kevin tells his favorite mistake story about the launch of “Spotify Now” when he was an engineering leader at Spotify. Why was there pressure to launch? What mistake did Kevin and team make regarding data from a small group of initial users? How did Spotify leverage its culture of “handling failure well”? What did Kevin learn?

Questions and Topics:

  • How do you balance the cost of lost customers vs. the cost of embarrassment?
  • Being surprised by the results of experiments
  • Was Spotify Now a problem of a bad concept or bad execution? Or Bad design?
  • Losing customers as “the cost of learning”
  • Organizational learning to not get into this situation again?
  • Doing retrospectives on EVERYTHING to remove the stigma?
  • The Forbes article that Kevin was quoted in
  • People who strongly believe in “accountability” — punishing failures — can you change their minds?
  • Failure vs. mistake? — how would you compare those words?
  • Tell us a little bit more about DistroKid – strengthening this culture of learning from mistakes?

name: Data Journey with Kevin Goldsmith (Anaconda) - Data & analytics used internally at Anaconda, SQL vs. Python, Layoffs and hiring in the tech sector, Agile data projects
author: Adam Kawa
summary:
Kevin Goldsmith works as a CTO at Anaconda, and he had previously worked in various roles at several companies e.g. CTO at Onfido and Avvo, as well as VP of Engineering at Spotify. He is also a Board Member and Advisor at several companies.

Anaconda is the most popular open-source distribution of the Python and R programming languages for data science that aims to simplify package management and deployment. Currently, ~30M practitioners from 235 countries and regions use Anaconda in their work.

Topics that we talk about:

  • What Anaconda is, who uses it and why
  • Data and analytics used internally by Anaconda
  • The role and responsibilities of CTO at Anaconda
  • SQL vs. Python in data science
  • Hiring and layoffs in the tech industry
  • An agile approach to data engineering and data science projects

The podcast was recorded by Adam Kawa (GetInData).

name: Will nationalism end the golden age of global AI collaboration?
author: Kate Kaye
summary: Until now, the borderless, open-source software movement that has helped bring together AI developers and tech from the U.S. and China has risen above geopolitical tensions. Could national security crackdowns tear it apart?

name: Work on your reputation inside and outside your company! with Kevin Goldsmith and Claudius Mbemba
author: Etienne de Bruin / Brittany Cotton
summary: Brittany Cotton and Etienne de Bruin talk to Kevin Goldsmith and Claudius Mbemba about the importance of building your reputation as CTO/VPE or technical executive.

name: AI IN ACTION E322: Kevin Goldsmith, Chief Technology Officer at Anaconda
author: JP Valentine
summary:
Today's guest is Kevin Goldsmith, Chief Technology Officer at Anaconda. With more than 20 million users, Anaconda is the world’s most popular data science platform and the foundation of modern machine learning. Anaconda pioneered the use of Python for data science and continue to steward open-source projects that make tomorrow’s innovations possible. Their enterprise-grade solutions enable corporate, research and academic institutions to harness the power of open source for competitive advantage, groundbreaking research and a better world.

Kevin is an experienced leader in high-performing product, research and shared technology engineering organizations. His technical areas of expertise include service scalability, user experience, consumer product development, GPGPU, multi-core, connected architectures, signal processing, domain-specific languages and graphics. Kevin currently oversees innovation for Anaconda's current open-source and commercial offerings, and develops new solutions to bring data science practitioners together with innovators, vendors and thought leaders in the industry.

In the episode, Kevin will discuss:

  • The work he does with Anaconda
  • Benefits that the Anaconda Nucleus brings to users
  • Company culture and what it’s like to work at Anaconda
  • Interesting projects and plans for growing the team
  • Upcoming AI trends that excite him in the industry

name: The power of collective autonomy with Kevin Goldsmith
author: Ruth Penfold
summary:
Kevin Goldsmith is a brilliant human who has led engineering teams with some phenomenal organisations. He’s someone who intentionally builds his teams to try to craft an environment where humans truly thrive and I love that about him.

He’s been reimagining how people show up together in teams for a while, and has a tonne of goodness to share with us all on some of the things he has been involved with.

We spoke of things like:

✺ The magic of learning from what others are doing well, and calibrating that to your organisation, like Spotify did

✺ The power of building teams with the mindset of collective autonomy

✺ The importance of making other people a priority as a leader, having experienced how much harder it is for you to grow when you feel like you have a leader that doesn’t care

✺ The investment you have to make to be truly straightforward with others

Let’s reimagine and reinvent the idea of work together, to create a space where we can all thrive and feel like we belong ✺

name: Growing And Supporting The Data Science Community At Anaconda
author: Tobias Macey
summary: Data scientists are tasked with answering challenging questions using data that is often messy and incomplete. Anaconda is on a mission to make the lives of data professionals more manageable through creation and maintenance of high quality libraries and frameworks, the distribution of an easy to use Python distribution and package ecosystem, and high quality training material. In this episode Kevin Goldsmith, CTO of Anaconda, discusses the technical and social challenges faced by data scientists, the ways that the Python ecosystem has evolved to help address those difficulties, and how Anaconda is engaging with the community to provide high quality tools and education for this constantly changing practice.

name: Spotify Squad Models feat. Kevin Goldsmith, Former VPE of Spotify
author: David Subar
summary: Tonight's Fireside chat is hosted by Interna. This is the first of a series where we asked today's leaders to acknowledge what they have learned and how to innovate on product, strategy, and technology.

name: Scaling Up In Business And Finding Your Place In The System
author: Péter Váradi
summary: Kevin Goldsmith and Péter Váradi on leadership, startups vs. corporate culture and diversity at the workplace

name: The CTO Onboarding Process
author: Lewis Adams-Dunstan
publisher: Preparing the Un-Prepared - A Data-Driven Podcast
summary:
I have to say, this was one of the most interesting conversations that I've had on Preparing the Un-Prepared - A Data-Driven Podcast

Thank you Kevin Goldsmith at Anaconda, Inc. for giving me this opportunity to have you on the show.

What's crazy is that when the camera stopped rolling, me and Kevin continued chatting for another 30 minutes behind the scenes and there were so many good things that were missed in the recording. Maybe next time we'll have to book a 2-hour slot haha

Anyway, the most interesting takeaway for me was when Kevin explained about how a start-up of 5 people might not benefit from having a CTO with 25 years of experience whos managed teams of 100+ people. There's seemingly a huge amount of diversity in skill sets from one CTO to another and the job function changes wildly depending on the size of the company, headcount, the business needs etc.

Etienne was joined by Ashley Raiteri and Kevin Goldsmith to talk about all things CTOs.

name: The World After COVID-19
author: Marcin Kulawik
summary: Are you looking for advices how to survive #pandemiccovid19 and prepare for #newnormal2020? Are you ready to get them from #leadershiptalk?

name: Making Distributed Organizations More Effective
author: Ben Linders
summary: An autonomous team model with teams organized around geographical or time-zone proximity can make a distributed organization more effective. With the Reverse Conway Maneuver you can deliberately add or remove bottlenecks to better support the designs you are trying to build.

name: The Tech Leaders Podcast
author: Gareth Davies
summary: Gareth Interviews Kevin Goldsmith, CTO of London based, identity verification provider Onfido. An engineer by trade, Kevin cut his teeth at Microsoft in the 1990's, and was a member of the Windows Media, Windows CE, and Microsoft Research teams at a time when they were scaling into the global behemoth they are today. He was also the Director of Engineering at Adobe Systems for nine years through a similar growth trajectory and also the VP of Engineering, at Spotify where he led, both product development and streaming delivery during a crucial time. We cover the above along with his thoughts on quantum computing, technology innovation and keeping engineering teams motivated during a lockdown.

name: From Zero to CTO – Kevin Goldsmith
author: Andy Skipper
summary: Questions and answers

name: MI Stúdió - How to fight full-time fraudsters with computer vision
author: Levente Hörömpöli-Tóth
summary: Budapest, Hungary hosts Stretch, an annual leadership and management gathering by Prezi where top-notch experts share their thoughts on hot topics. That is where we headed to talk to Kevin Goldsmith, Chief Technology Officer of global identity verification provider Onfido about how computer vision is disrupting healthcare, transportation, manufacturing, and security.

name: The Modern CTO Podcast - Episode 121
author: Joel Beasley
summary: Today we are talking to Kevin Goldsmith, the CTO at Onfido. And we discuss how to coach people as your company scales, building accountability through a continuum of understanding and the most important thing you must do to get focused work done. All of this, right here, right now, on the Modern CTO Podcast!

name: Kevin Goldsmith on the Spotify model and rolling out progression at scale
author: Jonny Burch
summary:
As makers, we're great at designing and building products and experiences that people love. But one thing that we still can't do effectively is design our own careers.

With the help of regular contributors and special guests, I dig into why that is, tackling questions around managing vs making, missing manager tools, soft and hard skills and training, compensation and navigating a new job that's right for you.

We want to help managers to build more satisfying careers for their teams, and designers and makers everywhere to do work they truly love.

name: Kevin Goldsmith on Architecture and Organizational Design
author: Travis Kimmel
summary: Travis Kimmel talks with Kevin Goldsmith about the correspondence between organizational design and software architecture. Their conversation covers: what Conway’s Law is; Kevin’s experiences in different organizational structures (e.g., Avvo, Spotify, Adobe, and Microsoft) and how those structures influenced the software architecture; what the “Reverse Conway Maneuver” is and how organizations can leverage it; how organizations can evolve existing architectures.

name: Tech Leaders Q&A: Kevin Goldsmith, former VP of Engineering at Spotify and former Director of Engineering at Adobe, discusses the future of technology and engineering…
author: Francesca Greane
summary:
In Third Republic’s Tech Leaders Q&A series we speak with industry leaders to hear their thoughts on the ever-evolving technology landscape, and the resulting drive towards digital transformation that we are seeing affect almost every business in every industry.
We recently spoke with Kevin Goldsmith, CTO at Avvo and former Vice President of Engineering at Spotify. Prior to this, Kevin also worked at Adobe and Microsoft. Drawing on his experience from these businesses Kevin shared some of his past success and challenges, as well as his thoughts on how technology and engineering are impacting digital transformation efforts, where he believes the future of digital lies.

name: #LegalTechLives with Kevin Goldsmith, Chief Technology Officer at Avvo
author: Ava Chisling
summary: With right around 20 years of experience at Microsoft, Adobe and Spotify, Kevin explains why the “near green field” of legaltech has got him excited all over again.

name: Data-Driven Thinking for Continuous Improvement
author: Ben Linders
summary: Organizations need an objective way to measure performance and tie actions back to business outcomes to improve continuously. Avvo uses a data-driven decision framework with an autonomous team model and a practice of retrospectives to help people make better decisions and proposals for continuous improvement.

name: The cavnessHR Podcast - A talk with Kevin Goldsmith
author: Jason Cavness
summary: Our guest on the cavnessHR podcast is Kevin Goldsmith. Kevin is the Chief Technology Officer at Avvo in Seattle, overseeing all Development, Data, Dev Ops and IT teams.

name: Wired to improve: A toolkit for data-driven change management
summary: The strategy & equipment necessary to build a culture where people are adaptable to change - and advocates for improvement.

name: Geek of the Week: With Microsoft, Spotify and Adobe behind him, Kevin Goldsmith finds a home again in Seattle at Avvo
author: Kurt Schlosser
summary: Seattle’s evolving tech landscape can catch you by surprise, especially if you leave the city for a couple years and then return. That’s what happened to Kevin Goldsmith, CTO at the online legal marketplace Avvo.

name: Tech recruiting advice: How startups can compete against big companies to find the best talent
author: Taylor Soper
summary: For startups needing to hire employees, it can be tough to compete against the likes of Amazon, Microsoft, and other tech giants that offer lucrative salaries and benefits large companies have capacity to provide.

name: Avvo CTO: Tech leaders must embrace failure to get best work from DevOps teams
author: Caroline Donnelly
summary: Speaking at the Lead Developer conference in London, Avvo CTO Kevin Goldsmith warns tech leaders not to punish DevOps teams for project failures

name: Kevin Goldsmith: Companies must learn to deal wisely with errors
author: Sebastian Meyen
summary: A company culture built on the premise of avoiding failure hinders innovation. Sebastian Meyen, Chief Content Officer at S&S Media talked to Kevin Goldsmith about his experiences as CTO with Avvo and Spotify and the idea of a mistake-friendly culture.

name: What Your CTO Wants You to Know
author: Michelle Nickolaisen
summary: A few developers working hard can get a lot done, but it takes a well-rounded team with different skills and roles to build and grow a successful software product and company.

name: Drinking from the fire hose — an interview with Kevin Goldsmith
author: Marcin Konkel
summary: I had a chance to speak with Kevin at AgileByExample 2016 conference in Warsaw. Afterwards, I invited him for this interview.

name: Interview with Kevin Goldsmith, former Vice President Engineering Spotify
author: Ieva Treija
summary:
On the one hand you are a tech guy, on the other — leaderhip proffessional. I don’t even know which one of those two is more appropriate topic.
Certainly, since I came to Spotify, I focused a lot…

name: Avvo names Kevin Goldsmith Chief Technology Officer
author: Laura Morarity
summary: Avvo, Inc., the leading online legal marketplace connecting lawyers and consumers, today announced it has hired Kevin Goldsmith as Chief Technology Officer. He will report to Avvo Founder and CEO Mark Britton.

name: Kevin Goldsmith (Spotify) – "Organisation, Architecture, Autonomy and Accountability"
summary: Kevin Goldsmith (Spotify) – “Organisation, Architecture, Autonomy and Accountability” on AO Jobs

name: Microservices at Spotify
author: Ben Linders
summary: Spotify has been doing microservices for quite some years at large scale. Kevin Goldsmith, Vice President of Engineering at Spotify, talked about how Spotify uses microservices to break down architectures and be innovative at the GOTO Berlin 2015 conference. He argues that Microservices are easier to test, deploy and monitor than monolithic applications. Spotify also aims to have as few as possible dependencies in their product, and microservices are very helpful for that.

name: What's it like to work at Spotify?
author: Emma Tracey
summary: According to Kevin Goldsmith, VP of Engineering at Spotify, the Swedish music-streaming mammoth’s success all comes down to its team culture. We sat down with the Carnegie-Mellon educated, Chicago-native at MobiConf Krakow. Over a weak coffee and prior to a strong vodka, he told us all about the fine balance between autonomy and chaos, preserving start-up culture in a large organizations, his escape from Microsoft and why failure is all part and parcel of the life of a continuous improvement organization.

name: The cutting-edge firms that hire IT staff on personality over skills
author: Danny Palmer
summary: When searching for a candidate to fill a vacancy, it's a given that the IT leader looking for a new employee will want to hire the best person possible. While many would automatically gravitate towards...

name: Appowr in Budapest - Smartmobil 2014
summary: Coverage of the 2014 Smartmobil conference, featuring an interview with Kevin Goldsmith

name: Engineering Culture
summary: Spotify's director of engineering, Kevin Goldsmith, examines what makes a great engineering culture and why it's important.

name: Microsoft: Enclave Of Nerds, Or Artists?
summary:
The northwest corner of the United States is home to an arts colony of astounding vigor. The locals paint, draw, sculpt, create sonic art and even have their own orchestra, with rehearsals every Monday and concerts every season.
Is this cradle of creativity centered in Seattle? Portland?
Try Microsoft.
